24:I[78891,["529","static/chunks/529-b3a318fab494e03f.js","244","static/chunks/244-f8e89f92ed6eb924.js","839","static/chunks/839-b514104c7e948606.js","165","static/chunks/165-ae3b45f0d86ef78d.js","184","static/chunks/app/dashboard/roots/%5Broot%5D/page-e0a9e2c37c8cb20d.js"],"CardTitle"]
25:T488c,<entryFree id="n27637" key="ظَلَمَ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>1</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">ظَلَمَ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, aor.      
    <form n="infl">       
                     <orth orig="Bi" lang="ar">ظَلِمَ</orth>
                  </form>, has for its inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">ظَلْمٌ</foreign>, (M, Msb, K, and so in some copies of the S,) or   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27637-1" target="ظُلْمٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n27643"/></foreign>, (so in other copies of the S,) or both, (T,) or the latter is a simple subst., (T, M, Msb, TA,) which is put in the place of the inf. n., (TA, [and the same is indicated in the T and K by the saying that the proper inf. n. is with fet-h,]) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27637-2" target="مَظْلِمَةٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n27664"/></foreign>, (S, TA,) or this is likewise a simple subst., (Msb,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27637-3" target="مَظْلَمَةٌ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, [or this also is a simple subst.,] and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27637-4" target="ظِلَامٌ" n="4" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n27653"/></foreign> also is said to be an inf. n. like <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْمٌ</foreign>, these two being like <foreign lang="ar">لِبَاسٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">لُبْسٌ</foreign>, [or it is a simple subst. like as <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْمٌ</foreign> is said to be, or it is an inf. n. of 3, as such occurring in the middle of this paragraph,] or, accord. to Kr, it is pl. of <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْمٌ</foreign> [like as <foreign lang="ar">رِمَاحٌ</foreign> is pl. of <foreign lang="ar">رُمْحٌ</foreign>]: (TA:) [<foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمَ</foreign> when intrans. generally means <hi rend="ital">He did wrong;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tyrannically:</hi> and when trans., <hi rend="ital">he wronged;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">treated,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">used, wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tyrannically;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">he misused:</hi>] accord. to most of the lexicologists, (Er-Rághib, TA,) primarily, (As, T, S, Msb,)   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27637-5" target="الظُّلْمُ" n="5" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">the putting a thing in a place not its own; putting it in a wrong place; misplacing it:</hi> (As, T, S, M, Er-Rághib, Msb, K:) and it is <hi rend="ital">by exceeding</hi> or <hi rend="ital">by falling short,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">by deviating from the proper time and place:</hi> (Er-Rághib, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">the acting in whatsoever way one pleases in the disposal of the property of another:</hi> and <hi rend="ital">the transgressing the proper limit:</hi> (El-Munáwee, TA:) [i. e.] <hi rend="ital">the transgressing the proper limit much</hi> or <hi rend="ital">little:</hi> (Er-Rághib, TA:) or, accord. to some, it primarily signifies <foreign lang="ar">النَّقْص</foreign> [as meaning <hi rend="ital">the making to suffer loss,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">detriment</hi>]: (MF, TA:) and it is said to be of three kinds, <hi rend="ital">between man and God,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">between man and man,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">between a man and himself;</hi> every one of which three is really <foreign lang="ar">لِلنَّفْسِ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">a wrongdoing to oneself</hi>]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [when it is used as a simple subst.,] the pl. of <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْمٌ</foreign>, accord. to Kr. is <foreign lang="ar">ظِلَامٌ</foreign>, as mentioned above, and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27637-6" target="ظُلَامٌ" n="6" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n27652"/></foreign>, with damm, is said to be syn. with <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْمٌ</foreign>, or a pl. thereof, [of an extr. form, commonly regarded as that of a quasi-pl. n.,] like <foreign lang="ar">رُخَالٌ</foreign>. (TA.) One says, <foreign lang="ar">مَنِ ٱسْتَرْعَى الذِّئْبَ فَقَدْ ظَلَمَ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">He who asks,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">desires, the wolf to keep guard surely does wrong,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">puts a thing in a wrong place</hi>]: a prov. (S, Msb.) And <foreign lang="ar">مَنْ أَشْبَهَ أَبَاهُ فَمَا ظَلَمَ</foreign>, (As, T, S,) a prov., meaning [<hi rend="ital">Whoso resembles his father</hi> in a quality, or an attribute,] <hi rend="ital">he has not put the likeness in a wrong place.</hi> (As, T. [See art. <foreign lang="ar">شبه</foreign>.]) <foreign lang="ar">وَلَمْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">تَظْلِمْ مِنْهُ شَيْئًا</foreign>, in the Kur [xviii. 31], means <foreign lang="ar">وَلَمْ تَنْقُصْ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">And made not aught thereof to suffer loss,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">detriment</hi>]: (M, K:) and in like manner Fr explains the saying in the Kur [ii. 54 and vii. 160], <foreign lang="ar">وَمَا ظَلَمُونَا وَلٰكِنْ كَانُوا أَنْفُسَهُمْ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">يَظْلِمُونَ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">And they made not us to suffer loss,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">detriment,</hi> by that which they did, <hi rend="ital">but themselves they made to suffer loss,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">detriment:</hi> (T, TA:) in which sense it seems to be indicated in the A that the verb is tropical. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  It is also trans. by means of <foreign lang="ar">بِ</foreign>; as in the phrase in the Kur [vii. 101 and xvii. 61] <foreign lang="ar">فَظَلَمُوا بِهَا</foreign>, because the meaning is <foreign lang="ar">كَفَرُوا</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">And they disbelieved in them</hi>], referring to the <foreign lang="ar">آيَات</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">signs</hi>]; (M, TA; *) the verb having this meaning tropically or by implication; or being thus made trans. because implying the meaning of <foreign lang="ar">التَّكْذِيب</foreign>: or [the meaning is, and <hi rend="ital">they wronged</hi> themselves, or the people, <hi rend="ital">because of them;</hi> for], as some say, the <foreign lang="ar">ب</foreign> is causative, and the objective complement, i. e. <foreign lang="ar">أَنْفُسَهُمْ</foreign>, or <foreign lang="ar">النَّاسَ</foreign>, is suppressed. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  And it is doubly trans. by itself: (TA:) one says, <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمَهُ حَقَّهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">He made him to suffer loss,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">detriment, of his right,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">due;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">defrauded,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">despoiled,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">deprived, him of it</hi>]; and <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27637-7" target="تظلّمهُ" n="7" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar" select="n27637"/>حَقَّهُ</foreign>: (M, K:) [and] you say, <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27637-8" target="تَظَلَّمَنِى" n="8" type="5" subtype="FSO" lang="ar"/>فُلَانٌ</foreign>, [as well as <foreign lang="ar">تظلّمنى مَالِى</foreign>, occurring in a verse cited in the M,] meaning <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمَنِى مَالِى</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">Such a one caused me to suffer loss,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">of my property</hi>]. (S.) It is said in the Kur [iv. 44], <foreign lang="ar">إِنَّ ٱللّٰهَ لَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">يَظْلِمُ مِثْقَالَ ذَرَّةٍ</foreign>, for <foreign lang="ar">لَا يَظْلِمُهُمْ مِثْقَالَ ذَرَّةِ</foreign>, and the verb is made doubly trans. because the meaning is <foreign lang="ar">لَا يَسْلُبُهُمْ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">Verily God will not despoil them,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">deprive them, of the weight of one of the smallest of ants,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a grub of an ant,</hi> &amp;c.]: or <foreign lang="ar">مِثْقَالَ ذَرَّةٍ</foreign>, may be put in the place of the inf. n., for <foreign lang="ar">ظَلْمًا حَقِيرًا كَمِثْقَالِ ذَرَّةٍ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">with a paltry spoliation</hi> or <hi rend="ital">deprivation, such as the weight of one of the smallest of ants,</hi> &amp;c.]. (M.)          <sense type="b" n="4">-b4-</sense>  One says also, <foreign lang="ar">أَرَادَ ظِلَامَهُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">مُظَالَمَتَهُ</foreign>, [these two nouns being inf. ns. of   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27637-9" target="ظَالَمَهُ" n="9" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, or the former, as mentioned above, is, accord. to some, an inf. n. of <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمَ</foreign>,] meaning <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْمَهُ</foreign> or <foreign lang="ar">ظَلْمَهُ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">He desired the wronging,</hi> &amp;c., <hi rend="ital">of him</hi>]. (M, K.)          <sense type="b" n="5">-b5-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمَهُ</foreign>, inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْمٌ</foreign> [or <foreign lang="ar">ظَلْمٌ</foreign>?], also means <hi rend="ital">He imposed upon him a thing that was above his power,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ability.</hi> (TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">يُظْلَمُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">He is asked for a thing that is above his power,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ability.</hi> (S.)          <sense type="b" n="6">-b6-</sense>  And one says, <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمَ البَعِيرَ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">He slaughtered the camel without disease.</hi> (S, K, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">ظُلِمَتِ النَّاقَةُ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">The she-camel was slaughtered without disease:</hi> or <hi rend="ital">was covered without her desiring the stallion.</hi> (M.) And <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمَ الحِمَارُ الأَتَانَ</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">The he-ass leaped the she-ass</hi> (K, TA) <hi rend="ital">before her time:</hi> (TA:) or <hi rend="ital">when she was pregnant:</hi> (K, TA:) so in the A. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="7">-b7-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمَ الوَطْبَ</foreign>, (S, K,) inf. n. <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْمٌ</foreign> [or <foreign lang="ar">ظَلْمٌ</foreign>?], (S,) <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">He gave to drink of the milk of his skin before its becoming thick</hi> (S, K, TA) <hi rend="ital">and its butter's coming forth.</hi> (TA. [And the like is said in the T and M.]) And <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمَ القَوْمَ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">He gave to drink to the people,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">party,</hi> (T, M, K,) <hi rend="ital">milk before it had attained to maturity,</hi> (T, K,) as related on the authority of A 'Obeyd, (T,) or [<hi rend="ital">milk such as is termed</hi>] <foreign lang="ar">ظَلِيمَة</foreign>: (M:) but this is a mistake: it is related on the authority of Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà [i. e. Th] and AHeyth that one says, <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمْتُ السِّقَآءَ</foreign>, and <foreign lang="ar">اللَّبَنَ</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">I drank,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">gave to drink, what was in the skin,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">the milk, before its attaining to maturity and the extracting of its butter:</hi> accord. to ISk, one says, <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمْتُ وَطْبِىَ القَوْمَ</foreign>, [but I think that it is correctly <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمْتُ وَطْبِى لِلْقَومِ</foreign>, agreeably with a verse cited in the T and M,] meaning <hi rend="ital">I gave to drink</hi> [<hi rend="ital">to the people,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">party,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">the contents of my milk-skin before the thickening thereof.</hi> (T.) And <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمْتُهُ</foreign> is said of anything as meaning <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">I did it hastily,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">hurriedly, before its proper time,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">season.</hi> (M, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="8">-b8-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمْتُ الحَوْضَ</foreign> means <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">I made the watering-trough in a place in which watering-troughs should not be made.</hi> (ISk, T.) And <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمَ الأَرْضَ</foreign> means <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">He dug the ground in what was not the place of digging:</hi> (M, K, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">when it had not been dug before.</hi> (M.) And, said of a torrent, <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">It furrowed the earth in a place that was not furrowed.</hi> (T.) And <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">البِطَاحَ</foreign>, said of a torrent, <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">It reached the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بطاح</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">wide water-courses containing fine,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">broken, pebbles,</hi> &amp;c.], <hi rend="ital">not having reached them before.</hi> (A, TA.) And <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمَ الوَادِى</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">The water of the valley reached a place that it had not reached before.</hi> (Fr, T, S, K, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="9">-b9-</sense>  When men have added upon the grave other than its own earth, <foreign lang="ar">لَا تَظْلِمُوا</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  [<hi rend="ital">Transgress not ye the proper limit</hi>] is said to them. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="10">-b10-</sense>  And one says, <foreign lang="ar">لَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">تَظْلِمْ وَضَحَ الطَّرِيقِ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Turn not thou from the main part,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the beaten track, of the road.</hi> (M.) And <foreign lang="ar">لَا تَظْلِمْ عَنْهُ شَيْئَا</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Turn not thou from it at all.</hi> (T.) And <foreign lang="ar">لَزِمَ الطَّرِيقَ فَلَمْ يَظْلِمْهُ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [<hi rend="ital">He kept to the road, and</hi>] <hi rend="ital">did not turn from it to the right and left.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="11">-b11-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">مَا ظَلَمَكَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَنْ تَفْعَلَ</foreign> (T, K, TA) <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">What has prevented thy doing</hi> (K, TA) such a thing? (TA.) A man complained to Abu-l-Jarráh of his suffering indigestion from food that he had eaten, and he said to him, <foreign lang="ar">مَا ظَلَمَكَ أَنْ تَقِىْءَ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [<hi rend="ital">What has prevented thy vomiting?</hi>]. (Fr, T.) And one says, <foreign lang="ar">مَا ظَلَمَكَ عَنْ كَذَا</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">What has prevented thee from such a thing?</hi> (T.) Respecting the saying <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">قَالَ بَلَى يَا مَىَّ وَاليَوْمُ ظَلَمْ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [addressed by a man to a woman who had invited him to visit her], Fr says, they say that the meaning is <foreign lang="ar">حَقًّا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">Truly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in truth;</hi> i. e. <hi rend="ital">He said, Yes, O Meiya, truly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in truth,</hi> I will visit thee]; and it is a prov.; (T;) or <foreign lang="ar">اليَوْمُ ظَلَمَ</foreign>, or <foreign lang="ar">بَلَى وَاليَوْمُ ظَلَمَ</foreign>, is a prov.; (Meyd;) and thus it was expl. by IAar, as used in the manner of an oath: but Fr says, in my opinion the meaning is, <hi rend="ital">and a day in which is a cause of prevention shall not prevent me:</hi> [so that the words of the hemistich above may be rendered, <hi rend="ital">he said, Yes, O Meiya, though the day present an obstacle,</hi> for I will overcome every obstacle]: (T:) <pb n="1921"/> accord. to Kr, <foreign lang="ar">قَدِمَ فُلَانٌ وَاليَوْمُ ظَلَمَ</foreign> means <hi rend="ital">Such a one came truly,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in truth:</hi> [or it may be rendered <hi rend="ital">such a one came though the day presented an obstacle:</hi>] but in the saying <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">إِنَّ الفِرَاقَ اليَوْمَ وَاليَوْمُ ظَلَمْ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> the meaning is said by some to be <foreign lang="ar">وَاليَوْمُ ظَلَمَنَا</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">Verily separation is to-day, and the day has wronged</hi> (us)]: or, as some say, <foreign lang="ar">ظلم</foreign> here means, <hi rend="ital">has put the thing in a wrong place:</hi> (M:) accord. to ISk, the phrase <foreign lang="ar">وَاليَوْمُ ظَلَم</foreign> means [<hi rend="ital">And,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">but,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">though,</hi>] <hi rend="ital">the day has put the affair in a wrong place.</hi> (T.) [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 911.]       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">ظَلِمَ</foreign>, said of the night: see 4.    </entryFree>26:T13ef,<entryFree id="n27639" key="اظلم" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>4</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">اظلم</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, said of the night, (Fr, T, S, M, Msb, K,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27639-1" target="ظَلِمَ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, (Fr, T, S, K,) the latter with kesr, (S,) like <foreign lang="ar">سَمِعَ</foreign>, (K,) [erroneously written in the TT as from the M <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمَ</foreign>,] <hi rend="ital">It became dark;</hi> (S, K;) or <hi rend="ital">it became black;</hi> (M;) or <hi rend="ital">it came with its darkness.</hi> (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 19], <foreign lang="ar">وَإِذَا أَظْلَمَ عَلَيْهِمْ قَامُوا</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">And when it becomes dark to them they stand still</hi>]; the verb being intrans.: or, accord. to the Ksh, and Bd follows it, it may be trans. [so that the meaning is, <hi rend="ital">and when He makes</hi> their place <hi rend="ital">dark</hi> &amp;c.]; as is shown by another reading, which is <foreign lang="ar">أُظْلِمُوا</foreign>: accord. to AHei, it is known by transmission as only intrans.; but Z makes it to be trans. by itself; Ibn-Es-Saláh affirms it to be trans. and intrans.: and Az [so in the TA, but correctly ISd, in the M,] mentions the saying, <foreign lang="ar">تَكَلَّمَ فَأَظْلَمَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">عَلَيْنَا البَيعتَ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  [<hi rend="ital">He spoke, and made dark to us the house,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chamber,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tent</hi>], meaning he made us to hear what we disliked, or hated, the verb being trans. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">أَظْلَمُوا</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">They entered upon the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَام</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">darkness,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">beginning of night</hi>]: (S, M, Msb, K:) or, as in the Mufradát [of Er-Rághib], <hi rend="ital">they became in darkness.</hi> (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  And they said, <foreign lang="ar">مَا أَظْلَمَهُ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">ما أَضْوَأَهُ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">How dark is it!</hi> and <hi rend="ital">How light,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bright, is it!</hi>]; which is anomalous. (S, TA.)       <sense type="A" n="2">-A2-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">اظلم</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">الثَّغْرُ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">The front teeth glistened.</hi> (T, K.) Hence the saying [of a poet], <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">إِذَا مَا ٱجْتَلَى الرَّائِى إِلَيْهَا بِطَرْفِهِ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">غُرُوبَ ثَنَايَاهَا أَضَآءَ وَأَظْلَمَا</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [as though meaning, <hi rend="ital">When the beholder of her with his eye looks at the fineness,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">sharpness,</hi> (but <foreign lang="ar">غُرُوب</foreign> is variously explained,) <hi rend="ital">of her central teeth, it shines brightly, and glistens:</hi> but Az plainly indicates another meaning; i. e., <hi rend="ital">he sees</hi> (lit. <hi rend="ital">lights on,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">finds,</hi>) <hi rend="ital">brightness and lustre;</hi> for he immediately adds, without the intervention of <foreign lang="ar">وَ</foreign> or <foreign lang="ar">أَوْ</foreign>, evidently in relation to this verse,] <foreign lang="ar">أَضَآءَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">أَىْ أَصَابَ ضَوْءًا وَأَظْلَمَ أَصَابَ ظَلْمًا</foreign>: (T:) [and ISd cites the verse above with the substitution of <foreign lang="ar">بِعَينِهِ</foreign> for <foreign lang="ar">بِطَرْفِهِ</foreign> and of <foreign lang="ar">أَنَارَ</foreign> for <foreign lang="ar">أَضَآءَ</foreign> immediately after saying that] <foreign lang="ar">أَظْلَمَ</foreign> signifies <hi rend="ital">he looked at the teeth and saw lustre</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">الظَّلْمَ</foreign>). (M.) [In the K, next after the explanation of <foreign lang="ar">اظلم الثَّغْرُ</foreign> given above, it is added that <foreign lang="ar">اظلم</foreign> said of a man signifies <foreign lang="ar">أَصَابَ ظَلْمًا</foreign>: thus, with fet-h, to the <foreign lang="ar">ظ</foreign>, accord. to the TA: in my MS. copy of the K and in the CK, <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْمًا</foreign>, which is doubtless a mistranscription.]    </entryFree>27:T792,<entryFree id="n27639-4" key="تَظَلَّمَ">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>5</itype>        
                     <orth lang="ar">تَظَلَّمَ</orth>
                  </form>
                  <foreign lang="ar">تظلّم مِنْهُ</foreign> (T, S, M, K, [but in some copies of the S, <foreign lang="ar">منه</foreign> is omitted,]) <hi rend="ital">He complained of his</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْم</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">wrongdoing,</hi> &amp;c.], (S, M, K,) <foreign lang="ar">إِلَى الحَاكِمِ</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">to the judge</hi>]: (T:) in some copies of the S, <foreign lang="ar">تُظُلِّمَ</foreign>. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">تظلّم</foreign> signifies also <hi rend="ital">He transferred the responsibility for the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْم</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">wrongdoing,</hi> &amp;c.,] <hi rend="ital">upon himself,</hi> (M, K,) accord. to IAar, who has cited as an ex., <quote>
                     <L>
                        <foreign lang="ar">كَانَتْ إِذَا غَضِبَتْ عَلَىَّ تَظَلَّمَتْ</foreign>
                     </L> 
                  </quote> [as though meaning <hi rend="ital">She used, when she was angry with me, to transfer the responsibility for the wrongdoing upon herself;</hi> which may mean that she finally confessed the wrongdoing to be hers]; but [ISd says] I know not how that is: the <foreign lang="ar">تَظَلُّم</foreign> in this case is only the complaining of <foreign lang="ar">الظُّلْم</foreign>; for when she was angry with him, it was not allowable [to say] that she attributed the <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْم</foreign> to herself. (M.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  See also 1, former half, in two places.    </entryFree>28:T504,<entryFree id="n27640" key="تظالم القَوْمُ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>6</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">تظالم القَوْمُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> (S, M, Msb) <hi rend="ital">The people,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">company of men, treated,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">used, one another wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tyrannically</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">بَعْضُهُمْ بَعْضًا</foreign>). (M, Msb.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  And [hence] <foreign lang="ar">تَظَالَمَتِ المِعْزَى</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">The goats smote one another with their horns</hi> by reason of their being fat and having abundance of herbage. (IAar, M, TA.) One says, <foreign lang="ar">وَجَدْنَا أَرْضًا تَظَالَمَ مِعْزَاهَا</foreign> <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">We found a land whereof the goats smote one another with their horns</hi> by reason of satiety and liveliness. (T, TA.)    </entryFree>29:T564,<entryFree id="n27641" key="اِظَّلَمَ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <itype>8</itype>        
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">اِظَّلَمَ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> (T, S, M, K) and <foreign lang="ar">اِظْطَلَمَ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">اِطَّلَمَ</foreign>, (S, M,) which last is [said to be] the most usual, (S,) [but I have mostly found the first to be used,] of the measure <foreign lang="ar">اِفْتَعَلَ</foreign>, (S, M,) <hi rend="ital">He took upon himself</hi> [<hi rend="ital">the bearing of</hi>] <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْم</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">wrong,</hi> &amp;c.,] <hi rend="ital">in spite of difficulty, trouble,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">inconvenience:</hi> (S, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">he bore</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">الظُّلْم</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">wrong,</hi> &amp;c.,] (T, M, K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">willingly, being able to resist;</hi> (T, TA;) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27641-1" target="اِنْظَلَمَ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign> signifies [thus likewise, or] <hi rend="ital">he bore</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">الظُّلْم</foreign>. (S, M, K.)    </entryFree>2a:Ta19,<entryFree id="n27642" key="ظَلْمٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">ظَلْمٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> The <hi rend="ital">lustre,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">brightness, of gold.</hi> (Z, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  And hence, (Z, TA,) The <hi rend="ital">lustre</hi> (lit. <hi rend="ital">running water</hi>) <hi rend="ital">upon the teeth;</hi> (Lth, T, Z, TA;) the <hi rend="ital">lustre</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">مَآء</foreign>, S, M, K, and <foreign lang="ar">بَرِيق</foreign>, S, K) <hi rend="ital">of the teeth,</hi> (Lth, T, S, M, Z, K, TA,) <hi rend="ital">from the clearness of the colour, not from the saliva,</hi> (Lth, * T, * M,) <hi rend="ital">like blackness within the bone thereof, by reason of the intense whiteness,</hi> (S, K,) <hi rend="ital">resembling the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">فِرِنْد</foreign> [q. v.] <hi rend="ital">of the sword,</hi> (S, K,) or <hi rend="ital">appearing like the</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">فِرِنْد</foreign> [<hi rend="ital">of the sword</hi>], <hi rend="ital">so that one imagines that there is in it a blackness, by reason of the intense lustre and clearness:</hi> (M:) or, accord. to Sh, <hi rend="ital">whiteness of the teeth, as though there were upon it</hi> [<hi rend="ital">somewhat of</hi>] <hi rend="ital">a blackness:</hi> or, as Abu-l-'Abbás ElAhwal says, in the Expos. of the “ Kaabeeyeh, ” <hi rend="ital">lustre</hi> (lit. <hi rend="ital">running water</hi>) <hi rend="ital">of the teeth, such that one sees upon it, by reason of its intense clearness</hi> [app. meaning <hi rend="ital">transparency</hi>], <hi rend="ital">what resembles dustcolour and blackness:</hi> or, accord. to another explanation, <hi rend="ital">fineness,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thinness, and intense whiteness, of the teeth:</hi> (TA:) pl. <foreign lang="ar">ظُلُومٌ</foreign>. (S, M.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  Also <hi rend="ital">Snow:</hi> (M, K:) it is said to have this meaning: and the phrase <foreign lang="ar">مُشْرَبَةِ الثَّنَايَا بِمَآءِ الظَّلْمِ</foreign>, used by a poet, may mean [<hi rend="ital">Having the central teeth suffused with the lustre termed</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">ظَلْم</foreign>, as is indicated in the T and S, or] <hi rend="ital">with the water of snow.</hi> (Lth, T.)    </entryFree>2b:T91e,<entryFree id="n27644" key="لَقِيتُهُ أَدْنَى ظَلَمٍ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">لَقِيتُهُ أَدْنَى ظَلَمٍ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form>, (S, M, K,) or <foreign lang="ar">أَدْنَى ذِى ظَلَمٍ</foreign>, (K, TA, [in the CK <foreign lang="ar">اَوَّلَ ذِى ظَلَمٍ</foreign>,]) means <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">I met him the first of everything:</hi> (S, K, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">the first thing:</hi> (M:) or <hi rend="ital">when the darkness was becoming confused:</hi> (M, K:) or <foreign lang="ar">أَدْنَى ظَلَمٍ</foreign> means <hi rend="ital">near;</hi> (El-Umawee, S, M, K;) or <hi rend="ital">nearness:</hi> (M, K:) and one says, <foreign lang="ar">هُوَ مِنْكَ أَدْنَى ذِى ظَلَمٍ</foreign> [app. <hi rend="ital">He is near thee</hi>], and <foreign lang="ar">رَأَيْتُهُ أَدْنَى ذِى ظَلَمٍ</foreign> [app. <hi rend="ital">I saw him near</hi>]: (M:) and <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمٌ</foreign> is also <hi rend="ital">syn. with</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">شَخْصٌ</foreign> [as meaning <hi rend="ital">an object seen from a distance,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a person</hi>]; (K;) or, as some say, it has this meaning in the phrase <foreign lang="ar">أَدْنَى ظَلَمٍ</foreign> [so that <foreign lang="ar">لَقِيتُهُ أَدْنَى ظَلَمٍ</foreign> may mean <hi rend="ital">I met him the nearest object seen from a distance,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the nearest person</hi>]: (M:) and accord. to Kh, one says,   
      <foreign lang="ar">لَقِيتُهُ أَدْنَى <ref cref="n27644-1" target="ظُلْمَةٍ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar"/></foreign>, or <foreign lang="ar">أَوَّلَ ذِى ظُلْمَةٍ</foreign>, (as in different copies of the S,) meaning <hi rend="ital">I met him the first thing that obstructed my sight.</hi> (S.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمٌ</foreign> signifies also <hi rend="ital">A mountain:</hi> and the pl. is <foreign lang="ar">ظُلُومٌ</foreign>. (M, K.)    </entryFree>2c:T584,<entryFree id="n27645" key="ظُلَمٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">ظُلَمٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> an appellation of <hi rend="ital">Three nights</hi> (T, S, K) <hi rend="ital">of the lunar month</hi> (T, S) <hi rend="ital">next after the three called</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">دُرَعٌ</foreign>; (T, S, * K; *) so says A'Obeyd: (T:) thus called because of their darkness: (S:) the sing. is   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27645-1" target="ظَلْمَآءُ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n27650"/></foreign>; (T, S;) so that it is anomalous; for by rule it should be <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْمٌ</foreign>; (S;) and the sing. of <foreign lang="ar">دُرَعٌ</foreign> is <foreign lang="ar">دَرْعَآءُ</foreign>: so says A'Obeyd: but accord. to AHeyth and Mbr, the sings. are   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27645-2" target="ظُلْمَةٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n27647"/></foreign> and <pb n="1922"/> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">دُرْعَةٌ</foreign>, agreeably with rule; and this is the correct assertion. (T. [See more in art. <foreign lang="ar">درع</foreign>, voce <foreign lang="ar">أَدْرَعُ</foreign>.])    </entryFree>2d:T1468,<entryFree id="n27647" key="ظُلْمَةٌ" type="main">

                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>

      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27647-2" target="ظَلْمَآءُ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n27650"/></foreign> (S, M, Msb, K) <hi rend="ital">Darkness; contr. of</hi>

                  <foreign lang="ar">نُور</foreign>: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the <hi rend="ital">departure of light;</hi> as also   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27647-3" target="ظَلَامٌ" n="3" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n27651"/></foreign>; (M, K;) which last has no pl.; (T, TA;) or this last signifies the <hi rend="ital">beginning,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">first part, of night,</hi> (S, M, Msb,) <hi rend="ital">even though it be one in which the moon shines;</hi> and is said by Sb to be used only adverbially; one says, <foreign lang="ar">أَتَيْتُهُ ظَلَامًا</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">I came to him at night,</hi> and <foreign lang="ar">مَعَ الظَّلَامِ</foreign> i. e. <hi rend="ital">at the time of the night:</hi> (M, TA:) the pl. of <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْمَةٌ</foreign> is <foreign lang="ar">ظُلَمٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">ظُلُمَاتٌ</foreign> and <foreign lang="ar">ظُلَمَاتٌ</foreign> (T, S, Msb) and <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْمَاتٌ</foreign>, (S, Msb,) or, accord. to IB, the first of these pls. is of <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْمَةٌ</foreign> and the second is of <foreign lang="ar">ظُلُمَةٌ</foreign>. (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْمَةٌ</foreign> is also [tropically] used as a term for <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Ignorance:</hi> and <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">belief in a plurality of gods:</hi> and <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">transgression,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">unrighteousness:</hi> like as <foreign lang="ar">نُورٌ</foreign> is used as a term for their contraries: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and it is said in the A that <foreign lang="ar">الظُّلْمُ</foreign> is <foreign lang="ar">ظُلْمَةٌ</foreign>, like as <foreign lang="ar">العَدْلُ</foreign> is <foreign lang="ar">نُورٌ</foreign>.                   <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">ظَالِمٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> [<hi rend="ital">Acting wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tyrannically:</hi> and <hi rend="ital">wronging;</hi> or <hi rend="ital">treating,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">using, wrongfully,</hi> &amp;c.:] part. n. of <foreign lang="ar">ظَلَمَ</foreign>: (M, K:) and

                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">أَظْلَمُ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> [<hi rend="ital">More,</hi> and <hi rend="ital">most, wrongful, unjust, injurious,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tyrannical, in conduct</hi>]. El-Muärrij says, I heard an Arab of the desert say to his companion, <foreign lang="ar">أَظْلَمِى وَأَظْلَمُكَ فَفَعَلَ ٱللّٰهُ بِهِ</foreign>, meaning <hi rend="ital">The more wrongful in conduct of me and of thee</hi> [<hi rend="ital">may God do to him</hi> what He will do; i. e. may God punish him]. (T.) [And] one says, <foreign lang="ar">لَعَنَ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">ٱللّٰهُ أَظْلَمِى وَأَظْلَمَكَ</foreign> i. e. [<hi rend="ital">May God curse</hi>] <hi rend="ital">the more wrongful in conduct of us.</hi> (K. [But in the TA, a doubt is intimated as to the correctness of this latter saying.]) One says also, <foreign lang="ar">لَهُوَ أَظْلَمُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مِنْ حَيَّةٍ</foreign> [i. e. <hi rend="ital">Verily he is more wrongful in conduct than a serpent</hi>]: because it comes to a burrow which it has not excavated, and makes its abode in it: (Fr, T:) for it comes to the burrow of the [lizard called] <foreign lang="ar">ضَبّ</foreign>, and eats its young one, and takes up its abode in its burrow. (TA voce <foreign lang="ar">حَيَّةٌ</foreign>.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  And <foreign lang="ar">الأَظْلَمُ</foreign> is an appellation of <hi rend="ital">The</hi> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">ضَبّ</foreign>; because it eats its young ones. (TA.)    </entryFree>33:T6ef,<entryFree id="n27663" key="مُظْلِمٌ" type="main">

      <foreign lang="ar">أَمْرٌ <ref cref="n27663-1" target="مِظْلَامٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n27666"/></foreign>: (K:) [or,] accord. to Lh, one says   
      <foreign lang="ar">يَوْمٌ <ref cref="n27663-2" target="مِظْلَامٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n27666"/></foreign>, meaning <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">a day such that one knows not how to enter upon it.</hi> (M.)    </entryFree>34:Ta72,<entryFree id="n27664" key="مَظْلِمَةٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">مَظْلِمَةٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> and <foreign lang="ar">مَظْلَمَةٌ</foreign>: see 1, near the beginning.          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  Also the former, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and the latter likewise, mentioned by Ibn-Málik and ISd and IKtt, and <foreign lang="ar">مَظْلُمَةٌ</foreign>, which is disallowed <pb n="1923"/> by several but mentioned on the authority of Fr, and all three are mentioned in the Towsheeh and in copies of the S, (MF, TA,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27664-1" target="ظُلَامَةٌ" n="1" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n27656"/></foreign>, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and   
      <foreign lang="ar"> <ref cref="n27664-2" target="ظَلِيمَةٌ" n="2" type="1" subtype="WO" lang="ar" select="n27657"/></foreign>, (S, TA,) <hi rend="ital">A thing of which one has been defrauded;</hi> (M, K; [in the CK, <foreign lang="ar">تَظَلَّمَهُ</foreign> is erroneously put for <foreign lang="ar">تُظُلِّمَهُ</foreign>;]) <hi rend="ital">a thing of which thou hast been defrauded,</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">اَلَّتِى</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">ظُلِمْتَهَا</foreign>, T,) or <hi rend="ital">a thing that thou demandest,</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">مَا</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">تَطْلُبُهُ</foreign>, S, Msb,) <hi rend="ital">in the possession of the wrongdoer;</hi> (T, S, Msb;) a term for <hi rend="ital">a thing that has been taken from thee;</hi> (S; [thus, as is said in the M, the first is expl. by Sb;]) <hi rend="ital">a right,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">due, that has been taken from one wrongfully:</hi> (A, Mgh:) the pl. of <foreign lang="ar">مظلمة</foreign> is <foreign lang="ar">مَظَالِمُ</foreign>. (Mgh, TA.) In the phrase <foreign lang="ar">يَوْمُ المَظَالِمِ</foreign>, [meaning <hi rend="ital">The day</hi> of the demand <hi rend="ital">of things wrongfully taken,</hi> and particularly applied to the great day of judgment,] the prefixed noun [i. e. <foreign lang="ar">طَلَبِ</foreign>] is suppressed. (Mgh.) [Respecting the office termed <foreign lang="ar">النَّظَرُ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">فِى المَظَالِمِ</foreign> 
                  <hi rend="ital">The examination into wrongful exactions,</hi> see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., see. ed., i. 132.]    </entryFree>35:T5f1,<entryFree id="n27665" key="مُظَلَّمٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">مُظَلَّمٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  A house, or chamber, <hi rend="ital">decorated with pictures;</hi> (M, TA;) as though the pictures were put therein where they should not be: it is related in a trad. that the Prophet, having been invited to a repast, saw the house, or chamber, to be <foreign lang="ar">مُظَلَّم</foreign>, and turned away, not entering: (M:) or <hi rend="ital">adorned with gilding and silvering;</hi> an explanation disapproved by Az, but pronounced by Z to be correct, from <foreign lang="ar">الظَّلْمُ</foreign> signifying “ the lustre, and brightness, of gold. ” (TA.)          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  And <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  Herbage <hi rend="ital">spreading</hi> (<foreign lang="ar">مُنْبَثٌّ</foreign> [in the CK <foreign lang="ar">مُنْبَت</foreign>]) <hi rend="ital">upon the ground, not rained upon.</hi> (K, TA.)          <sense type="b" n="3">-b3-</sense>  Also, of birds, <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  The <foreign lang="ar">رَخَم</foreign> [or <hi rend="ital">vultur percnopterus</hi>], and <hi rend="ital">crows,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ravens.</hi> (IAar, M, K. *)    </entryFree>36:T60b,<entryFree id="n27667" key="مَظْلُومٌ" type="main">     
                  <form>       
                     <orth orig="" extent="full" lang="ar">مَظْلُومٌ</orth>
                     <orth extent="full" lang="ar">ذ</orth>
                  </form> [<hi rend="ital">Wronged; treated,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">used, wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tyrannically:</hi>          <sense type="b" n="2">-b2-</sense>  and hence used in other senses]: see <foreign lang="ar">ظَلِيمٌ</foreign>, in three places. <foreign lang="ar">أَرْضٌ مَظْلُومَةٌ</foreign> is also expl. as meaning <tropical>(tropical:)</tropical>  <hi rend="ital">Land that is dug in a place not proper for digging:</hi> (TA:) or <hi rend="ital">land in which a watering-trough has been dug, not being a proper place for digging it:</hi> (ISk, M:) or <hi rend="ital">land in which a well,</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a wateringtrough, has been dug, when there had not been any digging therein:</hi> (A, TA:) or <hi rend="ital">hard land, when it is dug.</hi> (Ham p. 56.) Also <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">Land upon which rain has not fallen.</hi> (T.) And <foreign lang="ar">بَلَدٌ</foreign> 
                  <foreign lang="ar">مَظْلُومٌ</foreign> <assumedtropical>(assumed tropical:)</assumedtropical>  <hi rend="ital">A country upon which rain has not fallen, and wherein is no pasturage for the camels upon which people journey.</hi> (T.)    </entryFree>11:["$","$Lc",null,{"direction":"row","alignItems":"flex-start","width":"100%","background":"white","padding":{"base":"16px
